author: Johnathan Denson

review: It plugs into your HDMI port AND a USB port OR the included AC adapter for it's power.  It allows me to stream whatever is displayed on my Android phone and with some Android apps, interfaces directly with the Chromecast so I can do other things on my phone without it being displayed on my TV.  The Chromecast plugin for Chrome Browser is in BETA so it works most of the time but can be flaky.  However this has nothing to do with the Chromecast hardware rather it's software counterpart.  I found that when casting from my PC, it's best when my PC is connected to a wired network connection rather than WiFi for optimal performance.  Maybe it's my surroundings, my network, my router, but it just works better that way.  I've had no performance issues broadcasting, from my Android phone, such as NFL games, Netflix, PocketCasts, or YouTube.If you have a TV that isn't "smart" meaning it doesn't have built in WiFi, you will find this device very handy and an inexpensive way to connect various media to your TV.  If you do have a "smart" TV, this device is little more than a novelty and doesn't bring much to the table.  With that said, with smartphones or tablets being in almost every modern household, this is a neat device and  affordable.

review: When it works, it works. When it doesn't, it's a right pain in the butt. I don't know if it's something that I'm doing wrong, but I've found this device to be very hit-or-miss.
